snippet.textDisplay:
I have 500mbps unlimited internet at home, and no Stadia. Why? I have a PS4 and the PS Go app. It allows me to play games away from home with or without the controller WITHOUT having to buy the exact game over again and pay a subscription for the privilege (aside from PlayStation plus)
Bottom line, my console still works for single player if my internet went down or subscription expired.
snippet.textOriginal:
I have 500mbps unlimited internet at home, and no Stadia. Why? I have a PS4 and the PS Go app. It allows me to play games away from home with or without the controller WITHOUT having to buy the exact game over again and pay a subscription for the privilege (aside from PlayStation plus)
Bottom line, my console still works for single player if my internet went down or subscription expired.

snippet.textDisplay: Stadia is not trying to provide what all the other subscription services do. What you're paying for is not access to an online library of games. It's more like the Ultra Violet version of gaming where the up side is the hard computing being handled on their end and not the consumer's. This begs the question, though... How in the world do they think they're gonna keep up with the demand of gamers around the world all streaming in HD all day long at the same time? With the appetite for entertainment only being surpassed by the technology to make it even heavier in its demands, this seems like an impossible task to me. In addition, this still pushes gamers out into the realm of virtual access only to all their games. The industry seems to forget how big we are into collecting and displaying our purchases. What exactly will Best Buy be putting on their shelves if there are no games to go there and buy?
snippet.textOriginal: Stadia is not trying to provide what all the other subscription services do. What you're paying for is not access to an online library of games. It's more like the Ultra Violet version of gaming where the up side is the hard computing being handled on their end and not the consumer's. This begs the question, though... How in the world do they think they're gonna keep up with the demand of gamers around the world all streaming in HD all day long at the same time? With the appetite for entertainment only being surpassed by the technology to make it even heavier in its demands, this seems like an impossible task to me. In addition, this still pushes gamers out into the realm of virtual access only to all their games. The industry seems to forget how big we are into collecting and displaying our purchases. What exactly will Best Buy be putting on their shelves if there are no games to go there and buy?

snippet.textDisplay:
Honestly, Stadia is DOA to me. I already have large libraries on Xbox and Switch which I can't access with Stadia and no interest in building yet another library on a service that I can't even use traveling or off-line. Travel use is out the window as public wifi is sketchy or non-existent, hotel wi-fi robust enough to support stadia is a premium service often, and cellular isn't suitable either with harsh data caps, poor latency, and limited bandwidth. At home, why would I want to stream my games instead of playing what I already own on consoles I already own where I would play them anyway?

If internet access was universal, low latency, and uncapped, I would still be uninterested in having to buy from yet another marketplace.

If internet access was universal, low latency, and uncapped, and I were a new prospective customer with no games in any of the other marketplaces/consoles? The cost of ownership and subscription service might be more compelling for a light-weight gamer in such case.
snippet.textOriginal:

Travel use is out the window as public wifi is sketchy or non-existent, hotel wi-fi robust enough to support stadia is a premium service often, and cellular isn't suitable either with harsh data caps, poor latency, and limited bandwidth. At home, why would I want to stream my games instead of playing what I already own on consoles I already own where I would play them anyway? 

If internet access was universal, low latency, and uncapped, I would still be uninterested in having to buy from yet another marketplace. 

If internet access was universal, low latency, and uncapped, and I were a new prospective customer with no games in any of the other marketplaces/consoles? The cost of ownership and subscription service might be more compelling for a light-weight gamer in such case.

snippet.textDisplay:
I wonder how much Google's image factors into the performance of Stadia?

The technology is interesting, but Google already knows way more about me than I'm entirely comfortable with, especially given how they're using (sometimes abusing) their position.

What would Stadia have to do to potentially gain my interest? Provide a way where they couldn't (not a promise that they wouldn't, but a verifiable mechanism where they couldn't ) extract any information from a paid Stadia account.

It's one thing to say that free access is funded by the value of the data they collect on me as I play, but as soon as they charge me anything for the service that data becomes my exclusive property, otherwise I'm not interested.

P.S. Tomorrow's Google Board Meeting:

Gameranx says we have competitors for Stadia? Bob, get your people to shadow ban results for Sony's and Microsoft's offerings on our search platform ... and include those search terms as Stadia keywords in Adsense. Thanks.
snippet.textOriginal:
I wonder how much Google's image factors into the performance of Stadia?

The technology is interesting, but Google already knows way more about me than I'm entirely comfortable with, especially given how they're using (sometimes abusing) their position.

What would Stadia have to do to potentially gain my interest?  Provide a way where they couldn't (not a promise that they wouldn't, but a verifiable mechanism where they *couldn't* ) extract *any* information from a paid Stadia account.

It's one thing to say that free access is funded by the value of the data they collect on me as I play, but as soon as they charge me anything for the service that data becomes my exclusive property, otherwise I'm not interested.

P.S.  Tomorrow's Google Board Meeting:

Gameranx says we have competitors for Stadia?  Bob, get your people to shadow ban results for Sony's and Microsoft's offerings on our search platform ... and include those search terms as Stadia keywords in Adsense.  Thanks.

snippet.textDisplay: Stadia has been absolutely flawless for me.  That could be because I have gigabit FIOS and a nearly flawless internet connection with all my Chromecasts' hard-wired, but to see what it CAN be with great internet...  Yeah it's amazing and streaming is definitely the future once internet ISP's step their game up.  No consoles, no downloads, no updates, no HOT consoles, no consoles to worry about malfunctioning, no updating hardware....  NO worries!

snippet.textDisplay: I'm def a "casual" gamer, and am honestly loving Stadia. Why? First off, I'm a Google person, with a Pixel, Chromebook, Chromecast, YouTube, Android everything. Coming from there, the interface is intuitive and seamless. I think you're overstating how complicated this is - I'm literally 70 yo and this was pick up and go from day one, with no confusion or issues, technical or transactional.  Second, if you've got crappy internet, that's not a Stadia issue, it's your internet that sucks. Fix that, it will help with lots of stuff not just Stadia. Third, maybe because I'm old, idk, but I way prefer PvE, and Stadia has been great that way for me with no stutter, lag, or diminution of image or action. Do I wish there was more free content? Sure!  (honestly Farm Simulator, wth). But it's building every month, and c'mon ten bucks, you spend that on coffee.  To me it's a convenient high quality platform which eliminates long download times, gets me in and out fast, and has the Google-verse vibe I appreciate.  I enjoy your videos, thanks for all the thoughtful and fun commentary!
snippet.textOriginal: I'm def a "casual" gamer, and am honestly loving Stadia. Why? First off, I'm a Google person, with a Pixel, Chromebook, Chromecast, YouTube, Android everything. Coming from there, the interface is intuitive and seamless. I think you're overstating how complicated this is - I'm literally 70 yo and this was pick up and go from day one, with no confusion or issues, technical or transactional.  Second, if you've got crappy internet, that's not a Stadia issue, it's your internet that sucks. Fix that, it will help with lots of stuff not just Stadia. Third, maybe because I'm old, idk, but I way prefer PvE, and Stadia has been great that way for me with no stutter, lag, or diminution of image or action. Do I wish there was more free content? Sure!  (honestly Farm Simulator, wth). But it's building every month, and c'mon ten bucks, you spend that on coffee.  To me it's a convenient high quality platform which eliminates long download times, gets me in and out fast, and has the Google-verse vibe I appreciate.  I enjoy your videos, thanks for all the thoughtful and fun commentary!

snippet.textDisplay: Honestly, I think of streaming as a nice like supplementary service to actually buy games, whether through physical copy (my personal favorite) or digital distribution. Because when it comes down to it, streaming is just renting games. The only reason I dont have a problem with GamePass is because the games themselves are free with the service. So I'm renting basically an unlimited amount of games (not accounting for hard drive space) for a set price. Stadia makes us buy games that we dont get to own. And unless you get the free version, the subscription itself will eventually cost you more than a console. This all added on top of the fact that in most places internet speed and bandwidth is just not up to the task necessary for streaming games, I think that Stadia is in a leaking boat. Maybe if you didnt have to pay for the games themselves it would work, after all Netflix and Spotify have proven streaming is viable when the cost of subscription gets you the library as a whole. But as it currently is I wouldn't touch stadia with a 10 foot pole
snippet.textOriginal: Honestly, I think of streaming as a nice like supplementary service to actually buy games, whether through physical copy (my personal favorite) or digital distribution. Because when it comes down to it, streaming is just renting games. The only reason I dont have a problem with GamePass is because the games themselves are free with the service. So I'm renting basically an unlimited amount of games (not accounting for hard drive space) for a set price. Stadia makes us buy games that we dont get to own. And unless you get the free version, the subscription itself will eventually cost you more than a console. This all added on top of the fact that in most places internet speed and bandwidth is just not up to the task necessary for streaming games, I think that Stadia is in a leaking boat. Maybe if you didnt have to pay for the games themselves it would work, after all Netflix and Spotify have proven streaming is viable when the cost of subscription gets you the library as a whole. But as it currently is I wouldn't touch stadia with a 10 foot pole

snippet.textDisplay:
“What could they do to make you want to play Stadia?”

...um, it costs 2x per year over PSN or Microsoft memberships and you get to rebuy your games and have a lower quality, inconsistent experience. The only people buying it are curiosity seekers and bloggers.

So, cut the price to $4 per month and give discounts on games you already own.

This is purely financial for me as I’m sure the tech will continue to improve. Since they are going to be losing vast amounts of money up front to stake a claim to the market before Microsoft of Sony get there, they have to get real and practically give it away to build the community then monetize later. Plain and simple.
snippet.textOriginal:
“What could they do to make you want to play Stadia?”

snippet.textDisplay: I really like the idea of being able to stream games from wherever I am, but realistically the only place I'd have a connection that could handle Stadia is my house. I have gigabit fiber at home, which is great, but I can also stream games to my phone from Steam, Xbox, and PS4 easily on LAN. It's also pretty easy to set up game streaming outside of my home network on all of those. The only advantage I can think of from Stadia would be that I could instantly play the games I purchase without waiting for them to install.
snippet.textOriginal: I really like the idea of being able to stream games from wherever I am, but realistically the only place I'd have a connection that could handle Stadia is my house. I have gigabit fiber at home, which is great, but I can also stream games to my phone from Steam, Xbox, and PS4 easily on LAN. It's also pretty easy to set up game streaming outside of my home network on all of those. The only advantage I can think of from Stadia would be that I could instantly play the games I purchase without waiting for them to install.

snippet.textDisplay: There is nothing google could do to make me buy a stadia or even use the service if there was no buy in.   I only buy my games on physical media.  I feel ripped off if I pay real money for just a download and this seems like even more of a ripoff than that.   Maybe if it was totally free to play... like Hulu where you pay X every month and can play anything on the service for free.... maybe that would make it worth it but short of that... no.
snippet.textOriginal: There is nothing google could do to make me buy a stadia or even use the service if there was no buy in.   I only buy my games on physical media.  I feel ripped off if I pay real money for just a download and this seems like even more of a ripoff than that.   Maybe if it was totally free to play... like Hulu where you pay X every month and can play anything on the service for free.... maybe that would make it worth it but short of that... no.

snippet.textDisplay: honestly, I don't want to pay full price ($60) for games I'm going to stream, I'm more old-fashioned and would rather have a physical copy vs a digital one, but now a streamed copy? idk chief

snippet.textDisplay: I’m still convinced Stadia is a dumpster fire and Google is going to dump it just like they did all their other experimental projects. I’m guessing they’ll reimburse players who have purchased games, possibly in Google Play credit or something like that so they keep the money in the end.

snippet.textDisplay: Is Stadia wifi only?  A lot of times LTE is faster than public wifi.  And a connection is a connection, or at least it should be that way.
